title: 103_s1701
content: The Act is titled the "Social Security Administration Services Preservation Act" and includes findings and purposes. The Congress finds that the effective administration of Social Security programs depends on public goodwill and acceptance, as well as the locations and appearances of offices to maintain public confidence and cooperation. The mission of the Social Security Administration impacts the lives of all U.S. citizens, necessitating readily accessible offices. The need for accessible Social Security Administration offices is crucial as it impacts the lives of all U.S. citizens, especially the handicapped and elderly. Discrepancies and inconsistencies exist in the procedures for closing, consolidating, and recategorizing offices. The procedures for decisions regarding Social Security Administration offices are often inconsistent and informal, leading to closures, moves, and recategorizations that do not adequately consider the interests of those affected. Changes in office status and location should not undermine public confidence in the program. The purpose of this Act is to ensure that the public interest is considered. The Act aims to protect public interest in decisions regarding Social Security Administration offices and establish fair procedures for closures, consolidations, and re-categorizations. The Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for consolidation, closing, or recategorization of Social Security Administration offices. The Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for consolidation, closing, or recategorization of Social Security Administration offices. Section 712 defines "adequate public notice" for the affected office, including posting formal notices and mailing written notices to employees, local press, public officials, community groups, welfare offices, and Members of Congress. The Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for office relocation, defined as any physical move of an office within the same political subdivision due to lease loss or space needs. The term "office" encompasses field offices, district offices, and hearings and appeals offices of the Social Security Administration. The Social Security Administration defines "political subdivision" as a component of a county or large city with a common civic identity, and "recategorize" as scaling down an office to a lesser status. The Administration must provide public notice before closing, consolidating, or recategorizing any office. The Social Security Administration must provide public notice at least 90 days before closing, consolidating, or recategorizing any office. When making such a decision, they must consider the impact on the community served, including public transportation availability. When deciding to close, consolidate, or reclassify an office, the Social Security Administration must consider the impact on the community, including public transportation availability, need for personal service, and effect on employees. The Social Security Administration must consider factors such as educational levels, literacy, impact on employees, and economic savings when making determinations to close offices. The Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner must approve all decisions to close full-time offices, with the authority to delegate other determinations. The Social Security Administration must consider various factors when deciding to close, consolidate, or recategorize offices. Any preliminary determination must be in writing and include findings on required considerations. A public hearing must be held upon request, no earlier than 60 days after public notice, and must cover all proposals affecting the office. The Social Security Administration must issue a final report within 30 days after a public hearing, incorporating all testimony and written comments received. The Social Security Administration must issue a final report within 30 days after a public hearing, incorporating all testimony and written comments received. The final report must specify the final determination of the affected office's status, be sent to the local community press and appropriate Members of Congress, and provide public notice that the full report can be viewed or obtained at the affected office. The final report must specify the determination of the affected office's status and can be viewed at the office without charge. Appeals can be made to the Commissioner of Social Security within 30 days of public notice. The Social Security Administration must adhere to specific criteria when making determinations on appeals. No office changes can occur during the 30-day appeal period. The agency must report all office details in its annual budget submission to Congress. The Social Security Administration must report all office closures and planned closures in its annual budget submission to Congress while any appeal is pending.
